Award.AwardTitle: Coordination Complexes with Multiple Inorganic Functional Groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funded through the NSF Chemical Synthesis program supports work in the research group of John F. Berry at the University of Wisconsin--Madison aimed at using multiple inorganic functional groups to promote multi-electron processes. Here an "inorganic functional group" is defined as a unit capable of at least one redox reaction. Thus, combining multiple functional groups should lead to the observation of multiple redox reactions available to the same molecule. For example, a compound having a Mo(II)-Mo(II) quadruple bond 'functional group' can undergo two-electron oxidation to yield a triply-bonded Mo(III)-Mo(III) species, and a metal-oxo 'functional group' can undergo two-electron oxygen atom transfer processes. These two functional groups can be combined in such a way as to permit reversible four-electron redox and O-atom transfer reactions to take place. In this work, the exploration of compounds that combine inorganic functional groups will provide a pathway towards the discovery of new multi-electron reactions. The inorganic functional groups to be studied range from metal-metal multiple bonds, including metal oxo, carbene, and nitrido compounds, to heterometallic species in which each metal serves as a separate functional group.

Multi-electron reactions are very important in chemistry as well as in biological processes. For example, multi-electron reductions of molecules such as molecular oxygen are not only biologically important, occurring in aerobic respiration, but also play key roles in important energy-related technologies, such as fuel cells and water splitting. A fundamental challenge in the chemical community is to improve the efficiency of such multi-electron reactions. New ways to facilitate multielectron chemistry are of great significance, and this award supports a conceptual advance aimed toward the discovery of new multi-electron reactions. This advance involves combining traits of different transition metal compounds, each individually capable of electron transfer, into new compounds able to perform multi-electron transfer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We worked to improve the efficiency of multi-electron reactions by exploring centers that can effect electron transfer as ‘inorganic functional groups’. The work resulted in preparation, characterization, and reactivity studies of new classes of multi-metallic compounds. Highlights include the study of metal-metal bonded compounds with appended redox-inactive Lewis acidic centers in which the additional Lewis acid increases the Lewis acidity of the multiply-bonded metal complex; investigation of single-molecule magnet behavior of heterometallic chain compounds; studies of the first heterotrimetallic chain compounds in which all three metals are from the second row of th etransition series; discovery of new ligand-exchange reactions that allowed us to prepare a systematic family of heterobimetallic Rh-Bi bonded compounds; we performed the first one-electron oxidation of the Rh-Bi species to study the paramagnetic cationic species and found the unpaired electron to be localized on Rh. Multi-electron reactions and multi-metallic compounds are important to many biological systems as well as energy applications. This work contributed to the learning and training of graduate and undergraduate researchers. In addition, we engaged high-school students in scientific activities through the Pre-College Enrichment Opportunity Program for Learning Excellence (PEOPLE) program at UW – Madison, an exciting outreach program focused on broadening participation in science to underrepresented minorities and economically disadvantaged high-school students.


Last Modified: 05/04/2019
Modified by: John F Berry
